utterances: The role of Spanish-language media in this election was unprecedented, says Andres Ramirez, vice president of Hispanic programs for NDN, a Democratic think tank.
They took it upon themselves to increase their coverage of the elections and the importance of participating politically.
They ran millions of dollars of PSAs to encourage Hispanics to register to vote and to participate.
Democrats targeted three western states they lost narrowly four years ago, Nevada, Colorado and New Mexico.
And in all of them, Latino participation increased dramatically, says Ramirez.
In 2004, Hispanics accounted for about eight percent of total turnout in Colorado.
In 2008, they accounted for 17 percent.
In Nevada, we saw turnout increase to 16 percent in 2008.
That is up from 10 percent in 2004.
And in New Mexico, it went from 31 percent to 41 percent.
A wide variety of organizations reached out to Latino voters.
In Las Vegas, 20-year-old carpenter Jose Hernandez (ph) says he heard from his union local.
They actually, you know, spoke to us and, you know, go vote and also held like early voting and stuff like that.
27 percent of Latino voters were from union households, according to exit polls.
69 percent opposed the war in Iraq, which was the big issue for Hernandez.
I got family in Iraq, and I just don't want to see it anymore.
Even in Florida, where Hispanic voters have traditionally backed Republicans, a majority supported Obama according to Arturo Vargas, head of the National Association of Latino Elected Officials.
He says Latinos focus on their interests, not the party.
The economy, the war in Iraq, access to healthcare, the need for comprehensive immigration reform.
He says that independent spirit, along with ballot-box clout, will make certain that outreach to Latino voters becomes a permanent part of presidential campaigns.
Ina Jaffe, NPR News, Las Vegas.
the retirement needs of some 3,400,000 Americans.
Mr. Ferguson is president and CEO of TIAA-CREF.
It stands for Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association - College Retirement Equities Fund.

TIAA-CREF is a huge retirement system that started out serving college professors and has branched out over the years to include people in many other nonprofit fields, including many in public broadcasting.
In fact, Roger Ferguson, I should acknowledge my very large interest in TIAA-CREF.
My future is in your hands.
Very well.
I'm glad to meet one of our participants, and I can reassure you that we are in good shape.
You've spoken of TIAA-CREF's emphasis on being on the long term.
How do people, say, who are in their 60s, who were or are still thinking of retiring over the course of 10 years, how can they think about the long term?
Well, the first thing that people have to recognize is that they will live in retirement for 25 years, 30 years, 35 or more.
I send notes out to people who have reached 100 years old and get a number of them back.
And so the focus on the long term should not change even if one is very close to retirement, or frankly even if one is in retirement.

As baby boomers hit retirement age, is there any question at all that TIAA-CREF might not be able to access all the funds that those people will need if they choose at that moment to take a payout of their assets?
No, we have no concern about that.
Now, we have been in existence for 90 years.
We've seen our retirees through the Great Depression, through the stagflation of the '70s, through a number of market cycles.
And we've managed well throughout all of that.
We still have the highest ratings that are available from all four of the rating agencies.
And the fact that we have maintained a long-term perspective is important.
We have very good risk management.
I'm pleased to say that we avoided much of the subprime crisis, for example.
And...
You say much of.
I mean, some exposure but...
Miniscule.
For a $420 billion institution, our subprime exposure was really insignificant and miniscule.
But everyone in the financial services sector now is facing some crisis of confidence.
You know, I can hear listeners checking the boxes as they hear you.
Yes, you got your clients through the Great Depression.
Lehman Brothers got them through the Civil War and the Depression.
Yes, the rating agencies have rated you very well, but the rating agencies were putting bogus ratings on subprime mortgage-backed securities.
People have lost confidence in these things.
Well, what we've seen, actually, is just the opposite here.
We are a sleep-easy brand.
A sleep-easy brand.
A sleep-easy brand.
We have seen our call volume spike, for sure.
But importantly, our participants are voting with their feet.
And we have seen an increase in our assets under management.
We've seen an increase in the assets flowing in.
Between September 1 and today, we've seen approximately $500 million of new assets flowing in.
So, indeed, the fact that we are a sleep-easy brand has given our participants a great deal of confidence.
And we are getting a vote of confidence from them with their money flowing in.
That's right.
And it used to be that Uighurs were overwhelmingly the dominant population here.
But now many Han Chinese have migrated to the area, and so experts say it may be about 50/50.
If the writers strike is making you curse you television for want of new material, you can always watch the picket lines.
They can hardly get more glamorous than this.
Screen actors and writers guild members mingle liberally, the glitterati and the neurotic.
Jay Leno and Vanessa Williams brought protesters snacks, while the likes of Tina Fey, John Oliver, and America Ferrera, walked the line.
For a writers' strike, somehow you'd expect the signs to be better.
But if picket camp can't hold your attention, there are always reruns.

Not sure what all ""The Wire"" devotees are talking about, secretly curious about ""Battlestar Galactica,"" want to remember why Josh Whedon's ""Buffy"" was such a cult favorite, time to hit your Netflicks or your TiVo, or see if your cable system carries TV Land.
What reruns are you most looking forward to during the writers strike?
Give us a call, 800-989-8255.
E-mail: talk@nor.org.
You can also comment on our blog, that's at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Joining us now is Tim Goodman, TV critic for the San Francisco Chronicle.
He's with us from his home today in Oakland, California.
Nice to have you on the program.
Thanks, Neal.
And we're already bereft of Colbert and Stewart and the late night yakkers, so, where should we turn, do you think?

Well, I did a column the other day on the Chronicle where I said, you know, obviously we're not going to get hit that hard by the strike until January, that's when a lot of new contents going to go away.

But there's no time like now to start getting into the - you know, your Netflicks cue and rearranging things and updating in your mind exactly what you're going to go to when we run out of content, because we will do that.

And I think there's a lot of really good dramas and really good comedies that, not only have people, you know, forgotten about or passed over - because there's so many offerings on television - but they may never had even heard of in the first place.
When they go back and find it, they'll be delighted.
Yeah.
And the first thing you suggest is, you know, empty your TiVo or your DVR.
Right.
Yeah, it's funny, Neal, it's actually been a year ago in the Chronicle, I started calling this term called TiNo, which - meaning you'd TiVo it but you don't watch it.
And I think now that - that's about a year old now, I think we can actually empty the TiVo out, we can actually watch all the shows that we TiNo'd and didn't watch, we can get to those right away.
A lot of those - a lot of Ken Burn's hours, you figure, in that category?
Yeah - you know, I actually suggested that one of things people should do immediately is definitely go back and watch the war.
It was far and away the best thing of fall, anyway.
This was a week fall slate from the network and so this is a good chance for people to go back and get those out of the way.
Mm-hmm.
And not castor oil at all, fun to watch.
Oh, yeah.
I mean, educational and - you know, I joked about it.
I've interviewed Ken a number of times and, you know, I joked, you know, that it was going to take forever for people to get to their TiVo's on this thing.
But I think - it's 15 and a half hours and I just thought it was just phenomenal.
I could have actually - at the end of that, you know, it's not a joke, I could have watched 15 more.
Hmm.
Here's an e-mail from John(ph) in Davis, California.
During the writers strike, we must absolutely bring back Fox's ""Arrested Development."" Long live the Bluth Company.
My favorite quote form the show, I've made a huge mistake.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right.
Yes, ""Arrested Development,"" oh, on one of my top list.
It's funny because I think that as we go along - you know, I didn't want to overwhelm people, they've been given 20,000 choices, but maybe now's a good time.

Arrested Development,"" I think, is one of the - it ran three seasons on Fox, but it is definitely one of the most underappreciated sitcoms ever done on television, because it was so sly and so understated.
And, you know, I've said before, I think that there's like a 4-to-1 joke ratio compared to your standard sitcoms.
And now would be a really good time to go back start with that first season and rent that, and start to see just how brilliant those guys were.
Wait a minute, go back, rent the DVDs.
Isn't that what the writers are striking over, because they're going to get a dime?
Yeah, isn't it?
There's more of a bit of irony in this, of course, yes.
We're going to be - and that's why they're out.
I guess that could be our reminder that that's why they're out.
They didn't get a slice of that pie before and it really has fuelled - but, you know, it's fuelled television of late, but it's definitely fuelled the film industry.
But television jumped into it late and now that's just a really great revenue stream for them, and the writers want part of that.
Let's get another listener involved in the conversation.
By the way, if you'd like to join me and Tim Goodman as we discuss reruns we'd like to see during the writers strike, 800-989-8255.
E-mail is talk@npr.org.
Eric(ph) is with us.
Eric calling from Boise, Idaho.
Good afternoon, gentlemen.
Afternoon.
I am a huge fan of ""Saturday Night Live,"" and I'm sure that they will be impacted by the strike as well since they have to write fresh every week.
I would implore Lorne Michaels and the ""Saturday Night"" people.
Mr. Michaels, if you can hear me from the beach in St. Barths, let's just start from the top.
Why don't we watch reruns of the very first and the very second and the very third ""Saturday Nights"" that were made in 1975 and let's just enjoy - take it from the top.
And Lorne, if you see Dave Letterman down there, suggest the same thing to him.
Sounds like you're starting with episode one, you're buckling in for a long strike there.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, you bet.
But there's nothing better than the old ones.
